etymologies: Old English wāc ‘pliant’, ‘of little worth’, ‘not steadfast’, reinforced in Middle English by Old Norse veikr, from a Germanic base meaning ‘yield, give way’

definitions: lacking the power to perform physically demanding tasks; lacking physical strength and energy

examples.text: she was recovering from the flu and was very weak

shortDefinitions: lacking power to perform physically demanding tasks

definitions: lacking political or social power or influence

examples.text: the central government had grown too weak to impose order
the new king used his powers to protect the weak

definitions: (of a crew, team, or army) containing too few members or members of insufficient quality

examples.text: their problems arose from fielding weak teams in league matches

shortDefinitions: containing too few members or members of insufficient quality

definitions: (of a faculty or part of the body) not able to fulfill its functions properly
shortDefinitions: not able to fulfil its functions properly

definitions: of a low standard; performing or performed badly

examples.text: the choruses on this recording are weak

definitions: not convincing or logically forceful

examples.text: the argument is an extremely weak one

definitions: exerting only a small force
liable to break or give way under pressure; easily damaged

examples.text: the salamander's tail may be broken off at a weak spot near the base

shortDefinitions: liable to break or give way under pressure

definitions: lacking the force of character to hold to one's own decisions, beliefs, or principles; irresolute

examples.text: he was not weak or a compromiser

shortDefinitions: lacking force of character to hold to one's own decisions or principles

definitions: (of a belief, emotion, or attitude) not held or felt with such conviction or intensity as to prevent its being abandoned or dispelled

examples.text: their commitment to the project is weak

shortDefinitions: not held with conviction or intensity

definitions: not in a secure financial position

examples.text: people have no faith in weak banks

definitions: (of prices or a market) having a downward tendency.
shortDefinitions: (of prices or market) having downward tendency

definitions: lacking intensity or brightness

examples.text: a weak light from a single street lamp

definitions: (of a liquid or solution) heavily diluted
(of an acid) only slightly ionized.
displaying or characterized by a lack of enthusiasm or energy

examples.text: she managed a weak, nervous smile

shortDefinitions: displaying or characterized by lack of enthusiasm or energy

definitions: (of features) not striking or strongly marked

examples.text: his beard covered a weak chin

definitions: (of a syllable) unstressed.
denoting a class of verbs in Germanic languages that form the past tense and past participle by addition of a suffix (in English, typically -ed).

relating to or denoting the weakest of the known kinds of force between particles, which acts only at distances less than about 10⁻¹⁵ cm, is very much weaker than the electromagnetic and the strong interactions, and conserves neither strangeness, parity, nor isospin.
shortDefinitions: of weakest of known kinds of force between particles, which acts only at distances less than about 10 15 cm
